page.title: 10Ecology
page.content: The Churnet Valley is rich in wildlife and has a very varied collection of trees,plants,and shrubs. However some species have declined and left the district including mute swans which were to be seen on the Caldon Canal. About 80 species of birds have been recorded in the area,including 9 members of the warbler family and 3 species of woodpecker. Redpolls and siskins feed on Birches and Alder in the winter, kinfishers are to be seen on the canals. Many interesting plants, moths, butterflies, dragonflies, and blue damsel flies breed in the canal and marsh. There is an improvement in the pollution of the Churnet.The blue-grey slime which covered the bottom and sides has now been removed with a chemical which is harmless to fish and water plants. Fishing is now possible.
